children.subject:
Hi, Anon Helix!

I respect your opinion, but I'd like to counter this argument with an alternate perspective.

  1. I don't think it's fair to say that OP will "almost be like someone who hasn't seen the materials before." I'm currently an AI for CS 70, and I've had some students in class who are retaking the course after dropping it in a previous semester. Although their understanding was shaky in the past, they make use of any lingering mathematical intuition, which is difficult to forget.
  2. Taking CS 70 over the summer is really, really tough. The class moves at a super fast pace, and the lack of slower speed during the fall and spring semesters more than compensates for taking the course alongside others.
  3. Yes, the distribution seems more generous, but the class is never "curved." Rather, it's binned. And regardless, a stronger understanding will earn you a higher grade and is far more important than a slightly more favorable grade distribution.

OP, if you're all-in on trying to declare CS, I'd recommend taking CS 70 again in a better environment. That said, as you probably know, there are many other fantastic CS-related majors that are offered here, and perhaps you'd like to consider declaring another major if you don't want the setback of having to retake a course.

Ultimately, the choice is yours. Whatever you decide, best of luck!

I don't think you'll be at an advantage in the Fall if you dropped it in the summer. 

1. If you got -1 SD in the first midterm, I suspect that you have shaky understanding of the materials. That means if you dropped and retoke it in the Fall, and accounting for forgetting the materials during the time in between, you'll almost be like someone who hasn't seen the materials before, unless you spend that time in between summer and fall grinding for 70.

2. In the Fall, you'll be taking other classes with 70, which means less attention to 70 compared to summer where you're likely to be taking it with an easy class.  

3. Summer curve is usually more generous than Fall & Spring. Check Berkeley Times.

I think given the importance of this grade for declaring your major, taking it Fall will be your best option. While it is clear that there are deficiencies in understanding or pacing by the -1 SD, you are now aware of the work you needed to put in for that level of performance, and how to go about things better with a second chance. Rao's format means that Sahai's influence from Sp/Su20 should be shifted away so that the workload and test difficulty will shift back as well.

Also, with regards to summer curving, note that every summer at least 50-60 students on the lower end of the curve drop toward the end of the class, due to the flexibility offered for late drops by Summer Sessions. Other than the mild increase in difficulty from covering Stable Marriage, the class won't be worse in Fall. If this is the major you want to do, leaving time for EECS 16B will be pointless if you don't end up doing the major at all. 16B is a higher workload class compared to 188, so 70/188 would be the combo I would go for if I was 100% in on getting the CS major. Best of luck!

Hi! I was in your position and dropped and re-took the class. I'm really glad I did. Of course you have to do what you feel is best for you, but if you have the opportunity to drop it and re-take it, that's a great opportunity.

It's true that the summer curve could be a little bit better or that taking 70 on its own could be more manageable. I also think 188 is a pretty reasonable class, I think it's fun and isn't too crazy, there are great course notes, I think you can study the notes and past exams and do fine even if your focus is on 70. 

For me, 70 was still difficult the second time around (even with some review during the in-between time) but it wasn't new. And I learned from the first time around where my study strategy was lacking - for me, I realized I needed to prioritize doing almost all available past exams. Also, it was just fun to gain a better understanding of the fundamental material covered in the class which helped in future classes.

Sending you encouragement with whatever choice you make!

history.content:
Hi y’all, so I need some help.

Im taking cs70 right now & i performed -1 sd for the midterm & i am predicting that I will get a C+/B- which will equate to a cumulative cs gpa (including 61a and b) of 3.0/3.1 respectively. This would force me to appeal and Idk how good of a chance I would have to be accepted in this case. 

The other thing I could do is drop the class & take it in the fall. I would be at an advantage and the class is over a longer period of time and this would result in me getting a B/B+ which gives me a cs gpa of 3.2/3.3 respectively. 

In this case I may still have to appeal, but I have a better chance by like 0.1or 0.2. I’ll have to drop cs 188 or ee16b and im kinda sad about that but if its in my best interest I’ll do it. I know what the obvious and safe answer is but i just want to know if I really do have to retake it or do people get by with 3.0 gpas for cs? Or any other insight that y’all have.

Fall sem (w/o 70): cs188 & ee16b
Fall sem(w/ 70): 70 & 16b/188

Thanks in advance!
history.subject: Declaring CS
